DOC.HEAD: Lack of Coast Guard Regulations Cited As Contributing to Accident
DOC.TEXT: The Coast Guard's failure to require life rafts and signal beacons on small, commercial passenger boats contributed to the loss of life in the sinking of a vessel off the Oregon coast, the National Transportation Safety Board concluded Tuesday. It was the first time the board has cited what it considers a laxity in Coast Guard regulations as a contributory cause to an accident it investigated. The board, on a 3-0 vote with one member absent, placed primary blame for the accident on the vessel's captain, who was not identified. The board also blamed the Coast Guard for failing in its inspections to confirm whether hatchcovers on the 46-foot Cougar were watertight before the Sept. 15, 1988, sinking, which led to the deaths of the boat's captain, a deckhand and two passengers. One died 15 minutes before a helicopter rescued a ship's mate and the boat's four remaining passengers, who had floated in the cold water 35 miles west of Depoe Bay for 18 hours, investigators said. The board said the Cougar's captain had failed to ensure that hatchcovers were watertight, that the bilge pump was operating properly and that rubber flaps designed to let water flow off the deck were correctly installed. The flaps were on the wrong side, preventing water from flowing off the deck, investigators said. The ship sank in moderately heavy seas while returning from a fishing trip, after its crew and passengers tried for 90 minutes to bail out the ship with buckets. The board estimates that more than 4,700 commercial vessels capable of carrying 300,000 passengers fall under the same regulations as the Cougar. The board for years has recommended that the Coast Guard require all commercial boats to carry lifeboats that will keep all passengers and crew out of the water if the ship sinks and that emergency positon-indicating radio beacons, or EPRIBs, be carried on all vessels so they can be quickly located by searchers. In the last five years, the board has investigated five passenger vessel accidents, including two collisions, one fire, one capsizing and one grounding. In each case, Coast Guard survival craft requirements were found inadequate, but there has been no change. The board recommended that the Coast Guard require that within five years all floation devices and buoyant apparatus be replaced by lifeboats, life rafts or inflatable devices that can keep people out of the water. The problem is that floatation devices require that passengers remain in the water, where they can suffer from a rapid loss of body heat, or hypothermia. The board also advised the Coast Guard to improve its testing rules and procedures and to require all passenger vessel operators to file sailing plans before they set out.
